comments.commentBody:
Am I missing something?. Should one state be given this much attention and power by us, the candidates, the pundits, and the polls? The intense focus and brouhaha makes it seem and feel like by the end of the day, we will have a new president. The party atmosphere can make us temporarily forget that this is only one tiny step in a grueling process that will take months.

What about the natural herd instinct? Herd mentality. Shouldn't that be a concern? We humans tend to hop on bandwagons to associate with "winners" (even temporary winners) without even realizing what we are doing. If we're not cautious that can override critical thinking and change who we vote for. For example, it's possible that much of Donald Trump's popularity has to do with this bandwagon state of mind.

To point out another serious imbalance in our election system I, for example, like many of us, live in a Republican state. So when the time comes, my vote won't count. That's insane. Thus, in my opinion, we need to not only make less of what happens in Iowa and New Hampshire but also somehow get rid of gerrymandering and the electoral college and give everyone an equal one person one vote right to choose.

I am happy that a small, "fly-over" state gets the first place in the process.  When election night actually comes, because of the electoral vote process, the big states: California, New York, Florida, Ohio, Texas, will get all the attention.  It is good to see Iowa with its values and problems get attention now.

To suggest that "Iowa matters" is a product of 21st century's incessant need for instant gratification. History illustrates that you don't have to win Iowa to receive the nomination. Republicans Mitt Romney (2nd; 2012), John McCain (4th; 2008), George H. W. Bush (3rd; 1988), and Ronald Reagan (2nd; 1980) all received the nomination without Iowa. Democrats Bill Clinton (4th; 1992) and Michael Dukakis (3rd; 1988) also received the nomination without Iowa. Even further, the Citizen's United ruling will allow candidates to hang around after losing the Iowa Caucus badly because the Super-PAC money is still available for their campaigns. Yes, Iowa can set the tone for a couple of news cycles, but it clearly isn't as important as this op-ed makes it out to be.

Maybe I'm a hopeless romantic, but I find the fact that the presidential race is so heavily influenced by a small group of farmers in the Upper Plains and Yankees in Upper New England a rather charming return to the nation's rustic roots.

i lived in Iowa for more than a dozen years. I participated in every caucus except one. There wasn't much point to caucus in 2012!! I love that Iowa is the first in the nation to vote, and the intense attention residents receive from presidential candidates. There are few places in America that an average person can meet the candidates in the homes of friends & neighbors. It is something that I hope will be preserved for future generations. And the caucuses I've experienced are anything but, boring! Well, at least in the smaller rural communities. The county in which I lived and the 5 surrounding counties had a combined population of just under 50,000 in that 3,000 square mile area!

Having said that, my Yankeedom roots always provided me a nagging sense of disenfranchisement every 4 years. We only caucus for that one office, the president. In many communities there are no buildings with capacity to accommodate all eligible participants for either party. People who work evenings, don't have child care or transportation in mid-winter don't get to participate. Not to mention those who don't want others to know how they voted or a myriad of other reasons people avoid a public, physical participatory process. On the other hand, I never heard any of those people even discuss, let alone complain, about it.

Iowa IS a place of extremes! I was surprised to find that many liberals among those Fields of Opportunity! And who knew Iowa was in the Bible belt? I wish I was there today!

So, the New York Times considers Iowa to be "oddball", because it has the temerity to be primarily white and Christian and rural. Our country is based upon the Judeo-Christian values brought to this country by our forefathers. Yes, much of the country is still overwhelmingly white; I wasn't aware that being white was a bad thing. Yes, much of this country is rural as well; look out the window of the plane as you dismiss it as flyover country. Although New Yorkers may not realize it, much of the country has much more in common with Iowa and its' values than with New York City and the self absorbed big city coastal "elites". It serves you good to see what people outside the coastal bubbles think. We have to read and see what you think every day.

I'm glad that Iowa gets its' spot in the sun, aside from the ethanol fixation. We will hear about other voting blocks in other primaries and caucuses. It is one state out of 50, and the others will get their turn. Now, if only the southern 75% of Illinois could secede and join Iowa (we would also take Missouri, Indiana, or Kentucky).

I am a native Iowan who left the state for better opportunities elsewhere. I always follow the doings in my home state with familiarity and amazement. The Iowa Caucuses represent a huge financial boost for many Iowans every four years. As soon as they are over Iowa returns to normalcy as a fly-over state. The candidates won't be back any time soon.

As an Iowan I can channel the perceptions of my Hawkeye friends. I hear from them often. Here are some things that I'm hearing from the folks back home:

Trump: charismatic, pompous, narcissistic, ridiculous.
Clinton: artificial, out of touch, angry, fake, rich.
Cruz: nobody likes him, a chameleon.
Sanders: a curmudgeon, energetic, passionate, determined.
Rubio: absent, nervous, frustrated, immature.
Bush: cerebral, confused, unintelligible.
Carson: filled with the fire of Jesus, where's the fire extinguisher?

C'mon folks. We Iowans play a valuable role for the country. On the GOP side, we provide the USA guidance on who NOT to vote for, as we have put up for display with their Iowa trophies Santorum, Huckabee, plus, in close seconds, Pat Robertson and Pat Buchanan. And even when we get it right, i.e. Barack Obama, John Kerry, we still illustrate the fact that objects in the rear view mirror -- Hillary, Howard Dean, John Edwards--are farther away than they appear.

The comments keep repeating the same tired cliches, so in the future when you want to whine about the state’s unrepresentative demographics, just type “A.” If you’re complaining about how candidates must show fealty to the ethanol lobby, enter “B.” And if you’re whimpering that the state’s evangelicals exhibit too much control on the Republican side, a “C” will do nicely.

And if you want to declare that your Iowa-envy has become all-consuming, many of you will know that the letter “D” comes next.

Use "E" now to enter your own, terribly important reason for bashing the state.

"...and a showcase of how, on a good day, our democracy functions."   Surely you're joking!  Iowa represents NOTHING truly reflective of our country as a whole, and anoints candidates who have zero chance in the general election (Santorum.  Huckabee.)  All that catering to the extremely religious evangelical voter is completely out of step with the country in general.  And against the principles of separation of church and state clearly enshrined in the documents our founders created.  How our democracy MALfunctions would be more accurate.

Your system sounds great, if you want the winning candidates to always and forever be those who can buy coverage and attention nation-wide. The start-small system of primaries and caucuses, despite its quirks and evident flaws, at least gives a chance to candidates who cannot, early in their campaigns, afford ($) to project themselves into all 50 states.

As someone who was disappointment in the Times endorsement of Clinton,  I wish to point out to the editors that Iowa Democrats lean further left than many, due in part to the Scandinavian influences of the upper midwest. It is not just young people who are Sanders voters. Iowa has given us highly respected Democratic senators like Tom Harkin. We Sanders supporters are confident that our fellow progressives in Iowa will turn out in full force today.

The nominating process has to start somewhere, and no reason Iowa can't be first.  Does its electorate represent America today?  Not precisely, but then almost no other state matches exactly either.  So whichever state goes first, let's remember to not over-emphasize the results.  The big days, with multiple primaries, are coming.
